prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: With respect to the content of documents, it is suggested that confidential information should be fairly easy to isolate from other information which the recipient would be free to use and disclose following his or her departure. This would include information relating to trivial or insignificant business improvements or adaptations which will not merit protection.[1] Thus businesses should distinguish true confidential information from other information that is in the public domain, available within the industry, commonly known or insignificant.[2] Where ideas or information are still in the formative or conceptual stage, it should be pointed out to any recipient that this information may still be of significant value despite the fact that this value has not yet been realized.[3]
Attorney General v. Guardian Newspapers Ltd. (No. 2), [1988] 3 All E.R. 545 (H.L.).
Cooperheat of Canada Ltd. v. Slater (1973), 13 C.P.R. (2d) 25 (Ont. H.C.J.).

Talbot v. General Television Corporation Pty. Ltd., [1981] R.P.C. 1 (S.C. Vict.). See also Fraser v. Thames Television Ltd., [1983] 2 All E.R. 101 (Q.B.), at p. 121; Seager v. Copydex Ltd., [1967] 1 W.L.R. 923 (C.A.).
